item.title: Expressing support for the designation of the week of June 1, 2019, through June 9, 2019, as National Fishing and Boating Week.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Water, Oceans, and Wildlife.

item.text: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (text: CR 04/30/2019 S2523)
Passed/agreed to in Senate: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent.(text: CR 04/30/2019 S2523)
Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation discharged by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S3267-3268)
Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation discharged by Unanimous Consent.(consideration: CR S3267-3268)
Referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation.

summary.text: This resolution (1) designates the week of June 1-June 9, 2019, as National Fishing and Boating Week; and (2)recognizes that the recreational boating community and the boating industry should be commended for their numerous contributions to the economy, the well-being of citizens, and responsible environmental stewardship of water resources.

This resolution (1) designates the week of June 1-June 9, 2019, as National Fishing and Boating Week; and (2)recognizes that the recreational boating community and the boating industry should be commended for their numerous contributions to the economy, the well-being of citizens, and responsible environmental stewardship of water resources.

bill.title: A resolution expressing support for the designation of the week of June 1, 2019, through June 9, 2019, as "National Fishing and Boating Week".

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
